newsitem.title: USA: Sprint wins PCS licenses in 139 markets.
newsitem.headline: Sprint wins PCS licenses in 139 markets.

text.p: Sprint Corp said Tuesday it won the rights to personal communications services (PCS) licenses in 139 markets in the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) auction of wireless licenses.
Sprint said it bid $545 million in the auction, paying an average of $7.78 per person for each 10-megaHertz license.

Sprint said it projects build-out costs over three years of $1.5 billion. Costs associated with the licenses and build-out are expected to hurt earnings over the next few years, with peak dilution in 1998, Sprint said.
The build-out of many of the markets will begin immediately and take 12 to 14 months to complete, Sprint said. Other markets will be built out over a longer timeframe.

"We believe the long-term economic value created by Sprint PCS will far outweigh the start-up costs Sprint will incur," Bill Esrey, Sprint chairman, said in a statement. "Additionally, we believe the investment in a seamless, nationwide PCS network will pay off handsomely in the future as PCS becomes the universal standard for wireless communications in the United States."
Sprint said the licenses reach a total population of 70 million in cities across the contiguous United States and Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

The communications company said it bid in the latest auction with the objective to affiliate the new licenses with Sprint PCS. Sprint PCS is a joint venture of Sprint, Tele-Communications Inc, Cox Communications Inc and Comcast Corp.
Sprint said this partnership and its affiliates have licenses to provide PCS service to an aggregate population of 190 million people.
With the new licenses, Sprint PCS will reach nearly 260 million people.
Sprint PCS has launched service in eight markets, including Spokane, Wash., Milwaukee, Wis., Fresno and San Diego, Calif., Portland, Ore., Albany and Syracuse, N.Y., and Pittsburgh, Pa.

"The remaining markets, including New York, San Francisco, Dallas/Ft. Worth, Boston, Miami, Minneapolis/St. Paul, Denver, Seattle and Kansas City, will launch on a market-by-market basis in the first half of 1997," Andrew Sukawaty, Sprint PCS chief executive officer, said in a statement.

"When this first phase of launch is completed this year, Sprint PCS service will be available in 65 cities, including 35 of the top 50 U.S. markets," he added. "The addition of the new Sprint-acquired licenses will allow us to offer the many benefits of Sprint PCS to consumers and businesses in every metropolitan area including Atlanta, Chicago, Cleveland, Houston and Tampa."
